utterances: Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
It's the day after Christmas.
And if you live in Iowa, sleigh bells have likely been replaced by doorbells.
We've got NPR's political junkie Ken Rudin with us.
There are just eight days left until the caucuses and the campaigns are in high gear.
Have you ever gone door-to-door for a candidate in Iowa or New Hampshire?
Give us a call, why: 800-989-8255.
E-mail us: talk@npr.org.
And you can read what other listeners have to say at our blog: npr.org/blogofthenation.
And let's see if we can get a caller on the line.
And this is going to be Matt(ph), Matt's calling us from New Haven in Connecticut.
Hi, Neal.
Hi.
How are you?
I'm well.
Thanks, where did you go to a campaign?
Well, I ended up going to New Hampshire.
I was just out of college and I was in the midst of a switch of party affiliation.
I had been an active member of the college Republicans while in college, and soon after that I (unintelligible) irresponsible (unintelligible).
And I switched and became a Democrat.

And it was a very rude awakening for me personally because when I was in college, we were, well, the college Republicans would go on these trips and the Republican Party would pay for buses and they put us up in hotels and buy us beer.
And it was a jolly good time had by own.
My first experience with the Democrat, I volunteered for Howard Dean up in New Hampshire.
It was still quite early on the primary process, but I found myself paying my own way, sharing the bus and sleeping on the floor of the Manchester YMCA.
So…
Welcome to politics, Matt.
Exactly, yes.
And why did you feel so compelled to do it?
Well, you know, it was a lot of, I mean, as I said it was a bit early on, still in the process.
I like Howard Dean as a neighboring governor.
I'm from Connecticut, so I liked him when he was still about, you know, less than 2 percent in the polls.
And that to see him all of a sudden raising money and doing well in the polls and to see that he actually had a chance, I wanted to be a part of that.

And I took a trip in New Hampshire and actually ended up making some news on that trip because (unintelligible) I was going door-to-door when she was bit by a dog as we were knocking on doors and Howard Dean being a doctor, attended to her and…
And made a, you know, candidates saves campaign worker, right?
That's right.
Exactly.
And then it all, of course, fell apart very quickly.
Yeah, yeah.
It all led down to, you know, his scream.
The scream we remember every weekend on montage.
I heard it and I smiled as you led in today.
Well, thanks very much, Matt.
Appreciate the phone call.
By the way, this time around, are you as active as you were four years ago?
Work keeps me from being as active.
I've sent my money and I talked at my home state senator, Chris Dodd, as much as I can.
But I'm not able to go out the state at this point.
Okay.
Thanks a lot.
And, Ken Rudin, that seems to define a lot of young volunteers, people who have just graduated from college who can take time off and go door to door in some places just like New Hampshire.
Right.
New Hampshire is even a better state than Iowa because history shows that it's just tougher to get people out to commit in Iowa to the caucuses.
If you look at the number of people who participate in Iowa in the caucuses, far less than people than show up in the primaries.
But - two things about Howard Dean I want to mention.
One, I'm among the people who don't really feel that the scream is what really what did Howard Dean in.
Of course, his scream came at the end of losing the Iowa caucuses.

But it was interesting the day the Iowa caucuses before the results were in, Howard Dean had a comfortable lead in New Hampshire and once John Kerry won in Iowa, that lead, that Howard Dean lead in New Hampshire slipped away.
And I suspect that, again, whatever happens on January 3rd in Iowa is going to have tremendous revelations in New Hampshire five days later.
Let's talk about Tim(ph).
Tim's with us from Spokane in Washington.
Hello.
Hi, there.
You're on the air, go ahead, please.
Yeah, nice to meet - hear you guys.
I was just going down the highway and heard you make this - welcoming for people, making calls in.
I was in New Hampshire.
I was opening the Bradley campaign going against the former vice president Gore.
And so that was eight years ago.
Yeah, that was eight years ago.
It was great.
There was a couple I can't - quite honestly, I feel bad I don't remember their names - but they let me, the Bradley people arranged for me to stay at their homes.
He was some kind of a producer of television shows or something, I think, in New Hampshire.

And he and his wife let me stay upstairs in their home for a week, almost 10 days, and I just went around helping the Bradley people go door-to-door and got to do a lot of things with a lot of the Bradley people.
It was a really neat experience.
And most of this, I assume, was on your own dime.
Oh, yes, oh, that was.
I just came off from Northern California, flew out there and just decided to allot extra money and I do what I could with my money, help Bradley.
And then, of course, Mr. Howard Dean got involved in (unintelligible) went from there.
Hmm.
Well, it's…
And it kind of hurt.
Was it worth it in retrospect?
Absolutely.
I thought it was a great experience.
And I kind, if I could, I'd like to get out and help Barack Obama this year in Iowa.
I was hoping to try and get down there for a week, but it's all coming up real quick and I don't know if I'll (unintelligible).
Yeah, and I would wonder, the ideological difference is among the Democratic candidates - well, they're there, but they're not huge.
Why would you pick one over Barack Obama over Chris Dodd or Joe Biden or Hillary Clinton?
Well, quite honestly, I really wanted to support Hillary.
I think a lot of her.
I think she'd be a great president.
I guess the one thing that bothers me is just the family connection with Bill.
It's the idea that I just - it bothers me that the wife of a president would be ascending to the throne, so to speak, almost becomes something from the days of jolly old England, kings and queens.
Not a fan of dynasty, are you?
No, I'm not.
Okay.
And I like the idea that we've got a chance here to elect a bright fellow who I think could do a great job handling our nation.
Okay.
Thanks very much for the call.
I appreciate it.
You bet.
Thanks for taking it.
Well, let's get some more call on this in a minute.
But earlier this year, Sydney Rieckhoff entered a contest in Scholastic Magazine to report on the presidential election.
She is 9 years old.
She's already interviewed many of the candidates and their spouses.
Sydney Rieckhoff joins us now from her home in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.
Sydney, nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION today, welcome.
